title: Diploma in Retail Management
headline: Learn how to manage a retail outlet and ensure that it reaches its full potential with this free online diploma course.
description: Get to grips with running any kind of retail store with this diploma course. We explore all aspects of managing your own outlet, including choosing a location and hiring a cohesive team, budgeting, security and so on. We also delve into advertizing, marketing and managing your brand. This course suits anyone looking to polish their retail management skills, whether you are experienced or just starting out, so sign up to boost your career.
courseDescription:
This course examines every facet of store management in order to provide you with the skills needed to run your own retail outlet. We lay out the financial, marketing and legal processes behind running a store. We introduce you to the basics and study merchandizing, sales processes and stock management. We show you how to handle deliveries and hire a cohesive team of staff before studying different ways to manage disagreements or challenges that crop up, from late deliveries to store layout to staff conflict.

The course then navigates the processes of marketing and brand management and demonstrates how to communicate effectively with customers. Our module on retail psychology takes you through the concepts that explain your store’s recommended layout. We provide the skills that fuel effective management, including clear communication, problem-solving and proven research methods. Finally, we identify your health and safety responsibilities to your customers and staff and investigate the legal aspects of running a successful business. We highlight common potential legal issues and point you towards sources of guidance.

This course provides the necessary practical and theoretical skills to manage any store. We can help to refresh your existing management skills or equip you with an entirely new set of leadership abilities. This course can benefit small business owners but even if you have previous retail experience, we can help you to take a management track and your career to the next level.

  • Introduction to Merchandising

  • The way in which you merchandise the store is going to relate to the ability to generate additional sales from your customers.

    In general terms, ‘merchandising’ relates to the visual display of products within the store and making sure that the shelves are appropriately stocked. In addition, it relates to you having a variety of products available at any given time. It also relates to a retail outlet having set areas for set types of products. Customers prefer to be able to identify set areas where they can locate set products.

    Merchandising also relates to more than just the visual display of the products. It also means that you learn how to use the design of the product, the packaging of the product, the display, the selection, and even the thought process that goes into the location of the products and the order in which they are laid out.

    Merchandising also refers to the correct display of products that are reduced in some way or on any kind of a special offer. That is why you will often find retail outlets will have a set part of the store dedicated to these retail products.

  • Pricing

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • If you spend some time walking around stores it is amazing how often prices are either in the wrong place or are simply not being displayed correctly.

    The problem here is that this is going to be extremely frustrating for customers because they want to know how much something is going to cost them without having to hunt down a member of staff and then wait while they walk off in order to find out.
  • People want to know the price of something before they then purchase it as they will often work to a budget. People do not want to search for prices. They want to be able to see the price clearly, and to relate it directly to the product whether that be the label on the shelf or a price tag that is attached to the product in some way.

    If products are available at a special price, then they need to be aware of what that price is going to be and if there are any restrictions on how many of the items they can purchase at any given time. As a manager it is your responsibility to make sure that those items that are on offer have been put in the correct place.

  • Lesson Summary

    • The role of manager includes: dealing with the day to day running of the store, being in contact with the head office, dealing with staff and complaints from the public, overseeing the layout of the store, and implementing the correct way to run the store. 
    • Before you can progress to retail manager, you need to have some retail experience and work as a supervisor.
    • The six basic skills required for retail management are: 1. Patience. 2. Ingenuity. 3. People skills.
      4. Determination. 5. Creativity. 6. Comfortable with figures. 
    • Merchandising means the different products within the retail outlet, where they are located, and how they are displayed.
    • The three basic steps for effective merchandising are: 1. Full shelves. 2. Tidy displays. 3. Organised products.
    • The price of an item should be clearly displayed.
    • The organisation of a store is very important. The manager should inspect the layout of the store at least once a day.
    • Displays can be used to maximise sales. 
    • The five key points when designing displays are: 1. Organised and tidy. 2. Product must be obvious. 3. Price clearly displayed. 4. Stock must be replenished. 5. Sale materials used correctly.

  • Learning Outcomes

  • After successfully completing this module, you will be able to:
    • Outline the steps involved in using the checkout, and describe its basic requirements.
    • Describe the point of sale concept and its importance.
    • Classify the personal characteristics needed when dealing with this part of the process.
    • Define the meaning of the term consumer behaviour.
    • Interpret these definitions for the advantage of the company.
    • Analyse issues related to the behaviour of customers.
    • Visualise the difference these practises will make to your store.

  • The Checkout: Basic Requirements

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • The retail manager must follow each part of the sales process so that if something goes wrong it can be rectified as quickly as possible.

    When it comes to the checkout then you need to be able to understand the process that you have to work through to make sure that the customer gets the products that they want and in return you get the money for the products.
  • This part of the transaction should go as smoothly as possible: with the correct training there is virtually nothing that should go wrong thanks to the advances in technology.

    As the manager, you need to understand that even though there is less interaction with this part of the entire process that it is still extremely important and this cannot be overlooked. Training staff to deal with things in an adequate manner should be at the absolute core of your role as the manager because it comes back to resting on your shoulders as to whether or not they have been trained correctly. 

    You need to remember that any complaints that are made regarding your store will also come back to you.

  • The Importance of Trends

  • Why are trends are so important to your store? 

    It all boils down to this: the trend is going to be directly linked to something that people want to buy at the current time.

    If your store sells the kinds of products that are currently on trend, then it is essential that you are aware of the current trend so that the products in question can be displayed and merchandised correctly and that they are always available for customers to purchase. 

    Why should you be aware of trends? 

    You will very much come across as being on top of things and that can only be a positive when it comes to your reputation. Think of it this way. Would you be quite content if your retail outlet was seen as being backwards in its way of thinking? Would you want your store to be seen as the place where they just do not pay attention to what is going on and, therefore, why on earth should you bother to shop there?

    The answer to that is, of course not! Simply because of the negative way in which you are then going to be viewed. Now, if your competitors are not seen in the same light then where are people going to head in next to no time? The answer is most certainly not going to be in your door.

  • Retail Environment

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • The term "Retail Environment" refers to the environment within the retail outlet itself, which means every aspect of your store that the customer sees and interacts with from the moment that they walk in the door.
  • For example: the layout, the lighting, the products, the ease with which these products can be accessed, the checking out area, the pricing: every single thing that contributes in some way to the overall shopping feeling.

    However, there is a bit more to it than just that definition because there is a great deal of thought that has gone into creating the perfect retail environment for most people and even though you may not be involved in the creation of certain aspects, as they come from head office, that is not to say that you should take no interest in it.

    The retail environment is going to be separate to the overall store environment as that would include staff areas as well as store rooms. 

    However, we are only dealing with the parts of the store where customers are allowed to go: the layout of the store from the moment that customers walk in the door. The flow that exists in the store that makes it easier for people to move between the different items or areas of the store without them having to navigate between a sea of displays which will only irritate the customer.

  • We will begin by studying the importance of the relationship that has to exist between your store and your customers.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • Aside from trying to nurture that strong relationship, it makes sense for you to plan for the event of something going wrong.

    Just because there is a problem does not have to mean that the relationship has come to an end.   • The key here is in how you deal with the problems and one of the most testing things about being in retail management is that customers that are irate or upset about something will tend to ask to speak to the manager rather than dealing with the member of staff before them. This means that you need to be well versed in handling complaints so that, by the end of it, the relationship between store and customer has been somewhat resolved.

    You have to remember that no relationship is ever going to be perfect all of the time. Indeed, it is how you handle those issues that can help to strengthen the relationship even further.

    As the manager, it will be your job to pacify the customer and identify what the root problem is to then determine how best to tackle the issue head on. The first step here is acknowledging the issue.

  • Introduction to Stock Management

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • Stock management is the way in which you keep control of the products that are within your store, either on the shop floor or stored in the warehouse, so that you can replenish stock when it is needed.
  • Stock management is a fundamental part of running a store. 

    No retail outlet is going to be able to exist without stock and as the manager it is your responsibility to make sure that products are available to purchase at all times. In order to do this, you need to have a good understanding of stock management. 

    Without it, you are going to run into a number of issues since you can easily get to a point whereby you have too many of a product that you do not sell enough of and too little of a product that is loved by everybody.

    Even if you are working in a retail environment whereby the actual controlling of the stock is carried out by another member of staff, for example in a large supermarket, then that does not absolve you of responsibility. 

    As the manager, you must be aware of the bigger picture, and failing to correctly control stock management levels, resulting in products being missing from the shelves, is going to reflect poorly on your store.

  • The Importance of Location

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • Location is of huge importance to any retail outlet, not least because customers need to be able to find you. You also need to be in a position to take advantage of the passing trade that will go past your door on a daily basis. 

    Large companies are willing to pay huge sums of money to have a store in a particular location: why would they do that if location was not important?
  • The answer is obvious: There are certain areas where stores just have to be seen as their market almost expects it from them. The only problem with this is that they then have to still weigh up different options and study their market to see if it is worth their while spending the money to open up a new store. 
    After all, a small group of people in the area, although they may love certain products, is not enough for a company to then feel that this is the perfect location for them.

    However, this is not limited to large companies. Think about sections of cities where there is a more bohemian feel, with many of the same variety of stores. This happens because they know that this is the perfect location for their products as the correct market gathers in that location. There is market strength in knowing where your target market is and gathering there.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • Every aspect involved in setting up a retail outlet has been considered by a psychologist specialising in understanding the way in which we shop and things that can influence customers.
  • Here we will outline some simple tactics that can make a difference.

    Most of the time, if you walk into a supermarket you will be met with fresh flowers near the entrance and the first ‘section’ will be fresh fruit and vegetables. This is not a coincidence, or different supermarkets following the same blueprint with the layout. Rather, what they are doing is playing a psychological trick on the customer. 

    The idea here is that the freshness you experience will not only put you in a good mood, but it will also make you feel that the supermarket is clean and fresh.

    Subtlety is key in all of this, yet the power that lies behind some of these tricks within the psychology of the retail environment is so powerful that companies have invested millions into developing techniques or conducting studies that show how effective something is in helping to convince people to make a purchase.

    When a customer enters a store to purchase something, they often, have a clear idea of what they want – even if it is something rather general such as a new pair of shoes. However, the psychology of the store is designed to convince us that we need more than that and it all comes down to the art of persuasion.

  • Procedure for Receiving Goods

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • As soon as a supplier appears at your location you should be aware of what you need to do regarding paperwork on your part to satisfy your own accounts.

    You should be aware of the estimated delivery time and you must be prepared by having a copy of your order list ready. Upon the arrival of the goods, no matter how they are delivered, it is important that you check that the quantity of goods is as requested before you then put your signature on any kind of delivery paperwork.
  • This may be quite difficult when things are sent by courier, but you should still be able to check the details on the packaging to see how many are contained within a particular parcel. 

    This is your best chance to be sure that you have got what you asked for as you need to remember that you will have a limited period of time to get things changed if there is an issue.

    In addition to checking the quantity, you must check the price quoted on the delivery note, if this is part of the delivery.

  • Lesson Summary

    • Retail psychology is very important when it comes to designing a store.
    • Psychological tactics include: 1. Be friendly. 2. Introduce reusable bags. 3. Use seats. 4. Use items on sale to attract customers to the store.
    • Further common tactics are: 1. The ‘Compromise Price’ effect. 2. The ‘Treasure Hunt’ concept. 3. The ‘Accessory’ concept. 4. The 'Left Digit' effect.
    • Some potential issues with suppliers can be: 1. Problems with delivery. 2. Incorrect products. 3. Damaged goods. 4. Overcharging.
    • You must be very careful when choosing a supplier, and research very thoroughly.
    • Some things to consider when choosing a supplier: 1. Have you heard of them before? 2. Are they reliable?
      3. How quickly will they get products to you? 4. What is their ordering process like? 5. What are the terms?
      6. Are there any additional charges?
    • When receiving the goods, always make sure you check the correct quantity is present, the price is as agreed and that the paperwork is correct.
    • When dealing with damaged goods, make sure to have photographic evidence of the damage. You can also use this as an opportunity to build trust with your supplier.

  • The art of dealing with issues within your team is going to make a huge difference in the way that they are then able to work together. As the manager, this is going to lie directly upon your shoulders and it will be your responsibility to sort out whatever the problem may be and to do so as quickly as possible.

    In order to show how you can deal with certain issues, we should use several examples and describe how you are then able to rectify situations and get your team back on track.

    1. Conflict between team members.
    While it is impossible for you to make sure that everybody on your team likes one another, it is how you handle the situation when there is some kind of conflict that will prove to be the most interesting aspect of being a retail manager. If there is some conflict, it is important that you as the manager tackle things head on. You need to make sure that you get both parties together and get to the root of the problem to see if things can be resolved. It is not going to be good for the entire store if you allow ill feeling to fester between people.

    2. People doing the wrong jobs.
    In a busy store it is reasonable to assume that there may be moments where certain individuals will end up doing the job of other people. However, this is often due to a lack of organisational skills or a member of staff simply not pulling their weight, resulting in others feeling that they have to step in to make sure that a job is done. As the manager it is important that you find out why people are doing the wrong jobs to see how best to resolve the issue.

As the manager, this is going to lie directly upon your shoulders and it will be your responsibility to sort out whatever the problem may be and to do so as quickly as possible.

    In order to show how you can deal with certain issues, we should use several examples and describe how you are then able to rectify situations and get your team back on track.

    1. Conflict between team members.
    While it is impossible for you to make sure that everybody on your team likes one another, it is how you handle the situation when there is some kind of conflict that will prove to be the most interesting aspect of being a retail manager. If there is some conflict, it is important that you as the manager tackle things head on. You need to make sure that you get both parties together and get to the root of the problem to see if things can be resolved. It is not going to be good for the entire store if you allow ill feeling to fester between people.

    2. People doing the wrong jobs.
    In a busy store it is reasonable to assume that there may be moments where certain individuals will end up doing the job of other people. However, this is often due to a lack of organisational skills or a member of staff simply not pulling their weight, resulting in others feeling that they have to step in to make sure that a job is done. As the manager it is important that you find out why people are doing the wrong jobs to see how best to resolve the issue.

  • Basic Rules in Retail Marketing

  • The idea of any marketing is to make your client or customer base more aware of your existence in order to then encourage them to take that all important step and venture into your store and hopefully spend some money.

    1. You must offer a reason to get people in the door.
    One of the most basic things about retail marketing is there being a need to provide your potential customers with a good enough reason to actually come in your door in the first place. Perhaps it is something unique about your products or a service that you offer? Perhaps it is the prices that you charge that makes you so attractive? Think about why people would buy from your store and make sure that your marketing includes those key points.

    2. Pay attention to how you sell your products.
    You need to remember that there are so many options out there when it comes to purchasing products that there is a pretty good chance that the majority of your potential market will not actually need the things that you are trying to sell. This means that your marketing has to focus on the way in which you sell things and then making sure that you promote those areas so they feel drawn to your business as well as what you stock.

    3. Tie the marketing campaign in with your research.
    There can be no marketing of any kind without adequate research and thankfully that is now a lot easier due to software that can help you to analyse your sales. You need to be aware of areas of your business that may be lacking or need a boost. Your marketing should focus especially on those parts of your business.
